references.A02EVA01USGP: Evans, M.R., D.B. Lank, W.S. Boyd, and F. Cooke. 2002. A Comparison of the chracteristics and fate of Barrow's Goldeneye and Bufflehead nests in nest boxes and natural cavities. Condor. Vol 104 Issue 3, 610-619.
references.B93GAU01SEGP: Gauthier, G. 1993. Bufflehead (Bucephala alebeola).  In The Birds of Northa America, No. 67 (A. Pool and F. Gill, Eds).  Philadelphia: The Academy of Natural Sciences; Washington, D.C.: The American Ornithologists' Union.
references.B92AND01NAUS: Andrews, R., and R. Righter. 1992. Colorado birds:a reference to their distribution and habitat. Denver Museum Natural History xxxviii + 442 pp.
references.A91SAV02NAUS: Savard, J.-P. L., G. E. J. Smith, and J. N. M. Smith. 1991. Duckling mortality in Barrow's goldeneye and bufflehead broods. Auk 108:568-577.
references.B88ROO01NAUS: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
references.A88GAU01NAUS: Gauthier, G. 1988. Factors affecting nest-box use by buffleheads and other cavity-nesting birds. Wildl. Soc. Bull. 16:132-141.
references.R92VER01USGP: Vermeer, K. and K. H. Morgan. 1992. Marine bird populations and habitat use in a fjord on the west coast of Vancouver Island. Pages 86-95 in The ecology, status and conservation of marine and shoreline birds on the west coast of Vancouver Island. (Vermeer, K., R. W. Butler, and K. H. Morgan, Eds.) Can. Wildl. Serv. Occas. Pap. No. 75.
references.A87GAU01NAUS: Gauthier, G., and J. N. M. Smith. 1987. Territorial behaviour, nest-site availability, and breeding density in buffleheads. J. Anim. Ecol. 56:171-184.
references.B72ERS01USGP: Erskine, A. J. 1972. Buffleheads. Can. Wildl. Serv. Monogr. Ser. No. 4.
references.W09NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2009. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer. (Accessed: March, 2010 ).
references.B76BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F.C. 1976. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pa.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.A73STO01USGP: Stott, R. S. and D. P. Olson. 1973. Food-habitat relationship of sea ducks on the New Hampshire coastline. Ecology 54:996-1007.
references.A87GAU02USGP: Gauthier, G. 1987. The adaptive significance of territorial behaviour in breeding Buffleheads: a test of three hypotheses. Anim. Behav. 35:348-360.
references.A10LEM01USGP: Lemelin, L. V., M. Darveau, L. Imbeau, and D. Bordage. 2010. Wetland use and selection by breeding waterbirds in boreal forest, Quebec, Canada. Wetlands vol 30, number 2, 321-332.
references.B80BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F. C. 1980. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. 540 pp.
references.B78HAR01NAUS: Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.

habitat_description:
Northwest:
In general, habitats include Bay/sound, lagoon, river mouth/tidal river (Estuarine), low gradient (riverine), deep water, shallow water (lacustrine), riparian (palustrine), and conifer, Hardwood, and mixed forest and mixed woodland (Terrestrial).
Freshwater, permanent ponds with no outlet or only seasonal outflow, and small lakes. Large lakes avoided except by molting flocks. In the interior of BC, ponds used for nesting have only a small fringe of emergent vegetation (sometimes none at all) along the shore (Gauthier 1987). Ponds with extensive emergent or submergent vegetation avoided. Presence of poplar or aspen (Populus spp.) stands (a major cavity tree) near water is a frequent feature of breeding habitat (quoted directly from Gauthier 1993). This species breeds in areas with standing snags/hollow trees, bordering  lakes, ponds, rivers and seacoasts.  Nests in natural tree cavities, or abandoned flicker holes in tree cavities in mixed coniferous deciduous woodland near lakes and ponds (often return to same nest site in successive years).  For wintering and non-breeding periods, utilizes sheltered bays and estuaries as well as open freshwater situations. (Nature Serve).

Southwest:
Nevada: common winter visitor and fall months, seen in summer but not a breeder. Colorado: uncommon-common spring/fall migrant in western valleys, mountain parks and on eastern plains; rare winter resident (locally uncommon) in western valleys and on eastern plains; uncommon summer resident on eastern slope of Park Range, Jackson Co. - possible breeder. Casual nonbreeder in western valleys, other mountain parks, and on eastern plains. Nonbreeding in 5 states, year round in north and cental Colorado. Migration habitat: found in major river systems or water bodies in valleys. Winter habitat: on salt water (predominant winter habitat); inland: occurs on ponds, lakes, impoundments, or bays along slow moving rivers. New Mexico: common migrant and winter resident; rare and very local summer resident. Utilize freshwater and saltwater habitats. Found in the Rockies.

Great Plains/Upper Midwest:
Nests in prairie habitat only where stands of trees are present near water. Large lakes avoided except by molting flocks. Presence of poplar or aspen (Populus spp.) stands (a major cavity tree) near water is a frequent feature of breeding habitat (quoted directly from Gauthier 1993).

Southeast:
Buffleheads are a winter resident throughout the southeast.  They are primarily a coastal, salt water duck, feeding on crustaceans and molluscs in shallow water bays and inlets (Gauthier 1993). Inland buffleheads will occupy ponds, lakes, and slow-moving rivers (Gauthier 1993).

All Regions (winter):
On saltwater (predominant winter habitat), occupies more sheltered areas than goldeneyes. Along the coast, uses shallow waters in secluded coves, harbors, estuaries, or along beaches; avoids open coastlines (Erskine 1972, Stott and Olson 1973, Vermeer and Morgan 1992). Inland, occurs on ponds, lakes, impoundments or bays along slow-moving rivers (quoted directly from Gauthier 1993).
